questions.question: A 12-year-old girl with dengue hemorrhagic fever is being monitored by measuring platelet count. Spontaneous bleeding is associated with platelet values below/μL.
questions.explanation: Spontaneous bleeding (non-traumatic) is associated with platelet values below 20,000 platelets/μL. It most often involves small vessels. The common sites for such hemorrhages are: • Skin • Mucosa of gastrointestinal and genitourinary tracts • Intracranial bleeding - most feared site of bleeding. The production of the platelets is regulated by the hormone thrombopoietin produced in the liver. The platelet synthesis is also specifically increased by interleukin 6. The average lifespan of the platelets is 7-10 days. The normal platelet count is 150,000 - 400,000/µL.

questions.question: A 4-year-old girl with a history of easy bruising was referred for further evaluation. Herprevious lab reports showed that platelet count and morphology were normal. Plateletaggregations tests are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Glanzmann thrombasthenia.It is an abnormality of platelet GPIIb-IIIa (fibrinogen receptor). Platelets are unable to adhere toeach other and to the underlying tissue of the damaged blood vessels. It is inherited inan autosomal recessive manner. The symptoms include mucocutaneous bleeding in the neonatalperiod, menorrhagia, ecchymoses, epistaxis, and gingival hemorrhage..Types of Glanzmann thrombasthenia include:.Type 1: Absence of GPIIb-IIIa• Type 2: Reduced surface expression of GPIIb-IIIa/ Essentialis athrombia - clot retraction isnormal425• Type 3: Dysfunction of GPIIb-IIIaLaboratory features of Glanzmann thrombasthenia:• Normal platelet count and morphologyPlatelet aggregation occurs in response to ristocetin, but not to other agonists (such as ADP,thrombin, collagen or epinephrine)• Clot retraction is absent

questions.question: A 1-year-old boy is brought with a history of recurrent impetigo. Physical examination findings are given below. Platelet counts are low and peripheral smear shows abnormally small-sized platelets. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS). The given image shows (A) multiple petechiae over the face and hematoma under the right eye and (B) eczema of the foot. This syndrome is an X-linked recessive, primary immunodeficiency disorder involving the WAS gene. It is characterized by the triad of: • Severe eczema • Thrombocytopenia • Recurrent infections. Small platelets are seen in: • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome • X-linked thrombocytopenia. Large platelets are seen in: • Bernard-Soulier syndrome • Myeloproliferative syndrome • Myelodysplastic syndrome • May-Hegglin anomaly • Gray platelet syndrome.

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman presents with epistaxis, easy bruising and menorrhagia. There is nohistory of drug intake. Physical examination shows scattered petechiae and a normal-sizedspleen. Her lab investigations are given below. Antibodies against which of the following canlead to this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP).Autoantibodies seen in ITP are most often directed against platelet membrane glycoproteinsIIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It is a diagnosis of exclusion due to the following findings:•Bleeding tendency - petechiae• Low platelet count, elevated bleeding time•Presence of megathrombocytes in the peripheral smear - a sign of accelerated thrombopoiesis• Female preponderance426• Absence of splenomegalyNote: Prothrombin time (PT) is normal in ITP.

questions.question: Patients with which of the following predisposing conditions are likely to develop chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura?
questions.explanation: Systemic lupus erythematosus, HIV infection, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome can predispose to the development of secondary immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). The predisposing conditions of secondary chronic ITP include: Autoimmune conditions - Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS), immune thyroid disease, Evans syndrome, Lymphoproliferative diseases - Chronic lymphocytic leukemia, Large granular T-lymphocyte lymphocytic leukemia, Chronic infection - Helicobacter pylori, Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), Hepatitis C virus (HCV)

questions.question: Patients with which of the following conditions is associated with ADAMTS13 deficiency? a) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura, b) Hemolytic uremic syndrome, c) Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, d) Von Willebrand disease.
questions.explanation: ADAMTS13 deficiency is associated with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). ADAMTS13 is also called vWF metalloprotease, which degrades very high-molecular-weight multimers of von Willebrand factor (vWF). Its deficiency causes accumulation of these multimers in the plasma and promotes platelet activation and aggregation. TTP is a part of a spectrum of clinical syndromes called thrombotic microangiopathy. They are caused by insults that lead to excessive activation of platelets, which deposit as thrombi in small blood vessels. Features of TTP include: fever, thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, transient neurologic deficits, and renal failure.

questions.question: Deficiency of which of the following complement components is not associated with atypicalhemolytic uremic syndrome?
questions.explanation: Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome is not associated with deficiency of CD59.It is associated with deficiency of the following components:•Complement factor H• Membrane cofactor protein (CD46)• Complement factor IThese three proteins prevent excessive activation of the alternative complement pathway.Deficiencies of these proteins can be caused by inherited defects or acquired inhibitoryautoantibodies. The disease may be associated with a remitting, relapsing course.

questions.question: Coombs test is found to be positive in a patient with thrombocytopenia. Which of the following conditions could be a likely cause?
questions.explanation: Coombs test is positive in immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) as it is an immunogenic cause of thrombocytopenia. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) are non-immunogenic causes. Hence, Coombs test is negative in these conditions. Coomb's test detects RBCs from a patient with hemolytic anemia containing surface antibodies. Coomb's reagent (anti-human antibodies) is added. Direct Coomb's test: recipient's serum containing antibodies (Immunoglobulins). Reagent containing washed RBCs is added. Coomb's reagent binds to autoantibodies on RBCs and causes agglutination. Recipient Immunoglobulins get attached to the surface of these RBCs. Coomb's reagent (anti-human antibodies) are added. Indirect Coomb's test: agglutination occurs due to the presence of antibodies.

questions.question: Which of the following is affected in patients with Weber-Osler-Rendu syndrome?
questions.explanation: Weber-Osler-Rendu syndrome is a disorder of the blood vessels. It is an autosomal-dominant disorder caused by mutations that modulate TGF-β signalling. It is also known as hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia. This condition is characterized by dilated, tortuous blood vessels with thin walls that bleed readily. Bleeding is most common in the mucous membranes of the nose (epistaxis), tongue, mouth, and eyes, and throughout the gastrointestinal tract. Platelet count, prothrombin time (PT), and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) are normal. Clinical conditions in which abnormalities of vessel wall cause bleeding include: • Infections - meningococcemia, infective endocarditis, rickettsioses • Collagen defects - Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, scurvy, and Cushing's syndrome • Perivascular amyloidosis - most common with amyloid light-chain (AL) amyloidosis • Henoch-Schönlein purpura • Drug reactions
